page.title: 02A GLIMPSE OF BRECKLAND
page.content: Weeting Heath Nature Reserve was bought from Mr. Parrot but given to the Norfolk Naturalist Trust by Mr. Christopher Cadbury in 1942. It consists of 338 acres of sandy soil, open grassland, heath. Earlier it had been developed into an enclosed rabbit warren. It is famed for its birds, including Stone Curlew & Wheatear which have nested there for over 60 yrs. Among the flora are the rare Spiked Speedwell, Catchfly & Dianthus.Other great joys of the heath are butterflies & grasshoppers.Lanes or bridlepaths in the area are called "Drifts".The hedgerows either side boast many common wild flowers.One old footpath called the "Pad" exists across a housing estate.Forestry Commission woods are coniferous & the public can walk through them & see deer and other wild animals.
